Within the castle, the sept has rows of stained-glass windows honoring Garth Greenhand and the Seven. Highgarden's godswood houses three weirwoods known as the Three Singers. The palatial keep is adorned with statues and colonnades. Additionally, the castle features groves, fountains, and courtyards. The structures themselves are intertwined with ivy, grapevines, and climbing roses. Highgarden is a place of abundant flowers, filled with the melodies of singers, pipers, fiddlers, and harpers. The stables offer a splendid selection of horses. The fields surrounding the castle are adorned with golden roses that extend as far as the eye can see. Nearby orchards yield fruits such as melons, peaches, and fireplums.
72.name: Location: Highgarden

73.content: The Arbor is a golden island off the southwestern-most part of Westeros, ruled by House Redwyne. It is considered part of the Reach, and is separated from the mainland by the Redwyne Straits. It is protected by the Redwyne fleet, the largest fleet of the Seven Kingdoms. The Arbor is among the richest places of Westeros. The Arbor is known for making the best wine in Westeros, especially a terrific red one and a gold wine. Wine from the Arbor is usually sweeter than wine from Dorne. Peaches from the Arbor are huge and sweet. Traders from the Arbor have often sailed to Qarth. The Arbor has a warm and pleasant climate, due to its position surrounded by water off Westeros's southern coast.
73.name: Location: Arbor

74.content: House Fowler of Skyreach is a noble house from Skyreach in Dorne. They hold the title of "Warden of the Prince's Pass" and watch over the Prince's Pass. The sigil of House Fowler is a hooded azure hawk on an argent (silver) field. The words of House Fowler are "Let Me Soar". House Fowler are vassals of House Yronwood. The current lord of House Fowler is Franklyn Fowler, called the Old Hawk. He is the father of the Fowler twins: Jennelyn Fowler and Jeyne Fowler, both are tall women with wispy yellow hair. In their youth twins played with Princess Arianne Martell in the pools of the Water Gardens.
74.name: House: Fowler

75.content: House Allyrion of Godsgrace is a major Dornish noble house. Godsgrace sits near the confluence of the Scourge and the Vaith into the Greenblood. It is headed by Delonne Allyrion, the Lady of Godsgrace. Ser Ryon Allyrion is her son and heir. Ser Daemon Sand is Ryon's bastard son; Ryon has two more legitimate sons from Ynys Yronwood, his wife. Their blazon is a golden hand on gyronny red and black. Their words are "No Foe May Pass".
75.name: House: Allyrion

76.content: House Yronwood of Yronwood is the most powerful house in Dorne after the ruling Martells. Their seat, Yronwood, is the last fortress defending the Boneway; this is reflected in their title Warden of the Stone Way. Their words are "We Guard the Way". Their sigil is a black portcullis grill over sand. Yronwoods are stony dornishmen who tend to have blond hair and blue eyes. Lord Anders Yronwood is Lord of Yronwood, the Bloodroyal, and Warden of the Stone Way. Ynys Yronwood is Anders's eldest daughter, married to Ser Ryon Allyrion; she has at least two sons. Gwyneth Yronwood is Anders's youngest daughter. Ser Archibald Yronwood is Anders's cousin.
76.name: House: Yronwood

77.content: House Dayne, a vassal of House Martell in Dorne, holds the castle of Starfall. Their ancestral weapon is Dawn, a blade forged from a fallen star. The wielder of Dawn is bestowed the title "the Sword of the Morning". Daynes are known for their hair, which can be pale blond, dark, or silver with a black streak, and their eyes, often dark blue or purple. House Dayne has a cadet branch, House Dayne of High Hermitage. Their sigil displays a white sword and falling star on a lilac field. Notably, House Dayne has two tragic figures: Ser Arthur Dayne, the Sword of the Morning, who perished at the Skirmish at the Tower of Joy, and Lady Ashara Dayne, who took her own life at Starfall. The current ruler, Edric Dayne, possesses fair, pale blond hair and dark blue eyes that resemble purple. He wears a pale purple cloak. While initially shy, Edric is known for his good-natured and polite demeanor.
77.name: House: Dayne

78.content: House Martell of Sunspear is one of the Great Houses of Westeros and the ruling house of Dorne. They were never conquered by the Targaryens and have maintained a more isolated role in wider political events since Robert's Rebellion. House Martell's sigil is a red sun pierced by a golden spear, on an orange field.  Their house words are "Unbowed, Unbent, Unbroken." The Martells have a reputation for being fierce and resilient, with a strong sense of independence. House Martell has been known for its skilled warriors and strategic military tactics, particularly their expertise in guerrilla warfare. Their vassals are: House Allyrion, House Blackmont, House Dalt, House Dayne, House Gargalen, House Jordayne, House Manwoody, House Qorgyle, House Santagar, House Uller, House Yronwood. House Martell is currently ruled by Prince Doran Martell, the head of House Martell, from Sunspear in southeastern Dorne. Princess Arianne Martell is Doran's daughter and the heir to Sunspear. Prince Quentyn Martell is Doran's brother. Prince Oberyn Martell is Doran's brother, known for his combat skills and fiery spirit. Ellaria Sand is Oberyn’s paramour and mother of his daughters. Areo Hotah is the Captain of the guards at Sunspear. Manfrey Martell, a knight of House Martell and a cousin to Doran Martell, is the castellan of Sunspear.
78.name: House: Martell

79.content: Starfall is the ancestral castle of House Dayne in Dorne. The castle is located in the western Red Mountains on an island in the Torentine where it pours into the Summer Sea. Starfall includes a tower called the Palestone Sword.Northeast of Starfall is High Hermitage, the seat of a Dayne cadet branch.
79.name: Location: Starfall

80.content: The Water Gardens is a palace with gardens and waterworks that serves as a private retreat to House Martell, the rulers of Dorne. The Gardens are located on a beach next to the Summer Sea, three leagues to the west of Sunspear on a coastal road. Pale pink marble paves the gardens and courtyard. Terraces overlooking the numerous pools and fountains of the Water Gardens, shaded by blood orange trees. The Water Gardens are pleasant in autumn: hot days, cool nights, the salt breeze blowing in from the sea, and fountains and pools to admire and play in. Children from all stations and areas of Dorne are sent to the Water Gardens to foster, where they play together at the beach, pools and fountains, and in the water.
80.name: Location: Water Gardens

81.content: The Planky Town is a trading town that lies at the mouth of the Greenblood in Dorne, near Lemonwood. The largest and most populous settlement in Dorne, the Planky Town has a harbor that sees trading vessels. The town is the chief harbor of Dorne. The Planky Town is a settlement that floats upon the river. The houses, halls, and shops are made of poleboats, barges, and merchant ships, lashed together with hempen rope and floating on the tide.
81.name: Location: Planky Town

82.content: Sunspear, also known as the Old Palace, is where House Martell rules from and serves as the capital of Dorne. It's situated on the Broken Arm, which is north of the Greenblood along the far southeastern coast of Westeros. The castle is surrounded by the sea on three sides, with the shadow city on the fourth side. The Water Gardens, the palace, is located three leagues away on the coastal road. Doran Martell's captain of guards is Areo Hotah, and Caleotte and Myles serve as maesters for House Martell. Ricasso acts as the castle's seneschal, and Ser Manfrey Martell is the castellan. Alyse Ladybright holds the position of lord treasurer at Sunspear. Sunspear is a walled settlement, safeguarded by three massive Winding Walls that encircle each other. The Spear Tower, a tall and slender structure, stands at a height of one hundred and fifty feet and can house noble prisoners. The Tower of the Sun, a magnificent domed tower, contains the high seats of the Prince of Dorne. A portrait of Princess Daenerys Targaryen can be found hanging in Sunspear. The shadow city, adjacent to Sunspear, is a peculiar and dusty town built against one of Sunspear's walls, expanding westward. Further west, there are stables, inns, winesinks, and pillow houses, each with their own walls. Additional hovels have been constructed against these walls, resulting in a labyrinth of narrow alleys, homes, and bazaars.
82.name: Location: Sunspear

83.content: Brienne of Tarth, also known as the Maid of Tarth, is a noblewoman from the island of Tarth in the Stormlands of Westeros. At the age of 20, she is the only surviving child of Lord Selwyn Tarth, who raised her alone after her mother's death during childbirth. From a young age, Brienne displayed a strong and independent nature that set her apart from the expectations placed on noblewomen. At an impressive height of 6 feet 3 inches, Brienne possesses a muscular and robust physique, a result of her rigorous combat training. Her features are strong and broad, with sandy blonde hair kept short for practicality. Her most captivating trait is her piercing blue eyes. Brienne is renowned for her unwavering loyalty, integrity, and dedication to honor. Despite the challenges she faces due to her gender and appearance, she remains resolute in her pursuit of proving herself in a world that underestimates her. Independence and adherence to her principles, rooted in chivalry and knighthood, define her character. Having devoted her life to the art of combat, Brienne has become a remarkable warrior, defying societal expectations. Her prowess in swordplay, combined with her strength, agility, and determination, make her a formidable opponent on the battlefield. Additionally, her proficiency in horsemanship, gained through extensive training on Tarth, further enhances her skills. Brienne's dreams of becoming a knight. She idolizes the heroic knights of Westeros and avidly reads historical texts and tales that depict their valor. Her quest for honor and justice fuels her determination to always choose the right path, even in the face of adversity. Brienne's relationship with her father, Lord Selwyn Tarth, is complex. While he loves his daughter, he struggles to comprehend her aspirations of becoming a knight. Nevertheless, Brienne's unwavering resolve has earned her his reluctant respect. As a child, she was frequently ridiculed by her peers when dressed in female clothes, but she was once rescued from such mockery by a young Renly Baratheonю She has formed a close bond with Renly Baratheon, the younger brother of King Robert Baratheon, who recognizes her exceptional skill and appoints her to his personal guard.
83.name: Person: Brienne of Tarth

84.content: House Tarth of Evenfall Hall is a noble house from Evenfall Hall in the Stormlands. The family rules Tarth, a beautiful island northeast of Shipbreaker Bay that controls the Straits of Tarth between the island and mainland Westeros. They are one of the main houses sworn to House Baratheon of Storm's End. Their sigil is quartered with yellow suns on rose and white crescent moons on azure. Lord Selwyn Tarth is the head of the house, and his heir is Brienne Tarth, a formidable warrior. His lady wife died not long after the birth of Brienne.
84.name: House: Tarth

85.content: Lord Howland Reed is the head of House Reed of Greywater Watch. He is a crannogman, a member of a distinct group of people living in the swamps and marshes of the Neck in the North of Westeros. Crannogmen are known to be shorter and smaller than most men in Westeros. He is a loyal vassal of House Stark, ruling over the bog-filled lands of the Neck and the crannogmen. He first met the members of House Stark, including Brandon, Eddard, and Benjen, at the great tourney at Harrenhal when he was a young man. During the tourney, Howland was tormented by three squires until Lyanna Stark came to his defense. Howland fought alongside Eddard Stark during Robert's Rebellion and participated in the Skirmish at the Tower of Joy. He saved Eddard Stark's life during the battle by stabbing Ser Arthur Dayne from behind. Howland is known for his knowledge of the terrain and guerrilla tactics, which he uses to defend the North from invaders. He is skilled in combat. Howland is the father of Meera and Jojen Reed.
85.name: Person: Howland Reed

86.content: The Twins, also called the Crossing, is the home of House Frey in the northern riverlands. It's south of the bogs of the Neck and west of the kingsroad. The Twins is a strong fortress that consists of two identical castles, connected by a tower in the middle of the bridge. The castles are made of stone and stand on the banks of the Green Fork, where the river flows swiftly and deeply. Brenett is the maester of the castles, and Lame Lothar, one of Lord Walder Frey's sons, serves as the steward. Jinglebell, Walder's grandson, entertains as a fool, and Sedgekins works as a servant. They have high walls, deep moats, and a barbican and portcullis in each. Moats surround the castles, turning them into islands. The Lord of the Crossing sits in a great hall in the east castle on a tall and massive chair made of black oak. The back of the chair is carved to resemble two towers connected by an arched bridge. The maester's chambers are located in a turret accessible from Lord Frey's hall via a covered bridge. There's an apple orchard and a cornfield near the eastern castle, while hills can be found to the west.
86.name: Location: the Twins

87.content: The Hightower, also known as the High Tower, is the seat of House Hightower, one of the most influential families in the Reach. This castle and lighthouse combo is situated in the port of Oldtown, atop Battle Isle, where the Honeywine River widens into Whispering Sound. A massive stepped tower, it features a beacon at its pinnacle, guiding ships into the port. The beacon's fire can be altered, with the ability to emit green flames as a signal for House Hightower's banners to gather. The foundation of the castle holds a labyrinthine square fortress made of plain black stone, housing somber halls, vaults, and chambers. Within the Hightower, there is a grand hall located at a considerable height. The topmost part of the tower serves as the Lord of the Hightower's residence. Deep underground, one can find extensive vaults. The Hightower stands as the tallest structure in the Seven Kingdoms, surpassing even the seven-hundred-foot Wall.
87.name: Location: Hightower

88.content: House Tyrell of Highgarden is one of the Great Houses of the Seven Kingdoms. They are the rulers of the Reach. They are a wealthy and influential house, second only to House Lannister in terms of riches among the Great Houses. The Tyrells have the largest armies and, when combined with the Redwyne fleet, the lords of the Shield Islands, and the coastal lords, they possess a navy that rivals or even surpasses the royal fleet of King's Landing. Their sigil is a golden rose on a green background, and their motto is "Growing Strong." Members of the family typically have curly brown hair and brown eyes. The vassals of House Tyrell include House Ashford, House Caswell, House Florent, House Fossoway, House Hastwyck, House Hightower, House Leygood, House Merryweather, House Mullendore, House Redwyne, House Rowan, and House Tarly. Lord Mace Tyrell is the current head of House Tyrell, ruling from Highgarden. His son and heir, Willas Tyrell, is known for his intelligence and love for books, he has a crippled leg.  Garlan Tyrell, Mace's second son, is a skilled and honorable knight, often referred to as Garlan the Gallant; he is married to Leonette Fossoway and holds the title of Lord of Brightwater Keep. Margaery Tyrell, Mace's daughter, is a beautiful and ambitious woman skilled in courtly intrigue. Loras Tyrell, Mace's third son, is known as the "Knight of Flowers" and is highly skilled in jousting and warfare. Lady Olenna Tyrell, also known as Lady Olenna or the "Queen of Thorns," is the sharp-witted matriarch of the family and Mace's mother. Lady Mina Tyrell, Mace's sister, is married to Lord Paxter Redwyne. Lady Janna Tyrell, another sister of Mace, is married to Ser Jon Fossoway.
88.name: House: Tyrell

89.content: House Bolton of the Dreadfort is a Great House in Westeros. The Boltons are notorious for their brutal tradition of flaying enemies alive, which was depicted on their sigil—a flayed man. Their sigil is an inverted red flayed man with white, cross-shaped flayed skin behind him, set against a black background. Their motto is "Our Blades Are Sharp," while a commonly uttered phrase among their members is "A naked man has few secrets; a flayed man, none." House Bolton is sworn to House Stark, but they act in their own interests. There's a long history of tension between House Bolton and House Stark. House Bolton had several vassal houses: House Burley, House Harclay, House Knott, House Liddle, House Norrey, and House Wull. They also have vassals on Skagos, including House Crowl of Deepdown, House Magnar of Kingshouse, and House Stane of Driftwood Hall. Roose Bolton is the head of the house. Lady Walda is his current wife of House Frey. Ramsay Bolton is Roose's legitimized bastard son by a miller's wife.
89.name: House: Bolton

90.content: The Dreadfort is a fortress in the north and the seat of House Bolton in northeastern Westeros. Located on the banks of the upper Weeping Water, it is southeast of the Lonely Hills and north of the Sheepshead Hills. The Dreadfort is north of Hornwood, south of Last Hearth, and southwest of Karhold. Steelshanks Walton serves as Lord Roose Bolton's captain and Nage is one of his guards. Ben Bones is the castle's kennelmaster and Tybald serves as maester. Letters from the Dreadfort use pink sealing wax. The Dreadfort is a strong fortress, with high walls and triangular merlons that look like sharp stone teeth. Its great hall is dim and smoky, with rows of torches grasped by skeletal human hands jutting from the walls. Long tables stand before a dais with a high table. The hall has a vaulted ceiling and wooden rafters turned black from smoke. The Dreadfort is ill omened, for it is said the Boltons keep torture chambers and a special room where they hang the flayed skins of their enemies, including several Kings in the North. Boltons are buried beneath the Dreadfort.
90.name: Location: Dreadfort

91.content: House Karstark of Karhold is a noble house from Karhold in the north. They were founded as a cadet branch of their overlords, the Starks of Winterfell, and were among their principal bannermen. The sigil of House Karstark is a white sunburst on black. Their words are "The Sun of Winter". The head of the house is Lord Rickard Karstark. He has four children: Harrion, Eddard, Torrhen, and Alys.
91.name: House: Karstark

92.content:
The Gates of the Moon, also known as the Gates, is a castle at the base of the Giant's Lance in the Vale of Arryn. It is held by Lord Nestor Royce, High Steward of the Vale and Keeper of the Gates of the Moon, on behalf of House Arryn. Larger than the Eyrie, the Gates of the Moon is a stout castle with a moat, a gatehouse, a yard, and a well. The castle has square towers, include the East Tower and the Falcon Tower. The back of the castle's Great Hall has a pillared gallery which leads to tower stairs and to the inner ward. The castle's vaults contain granaries and dungeons. Prisoners can also be kept in tower cells. Guardsmen at the Gates of the Moon wear sky-blue cloaks.

At night torches flicker at the castle's ramparts and the moon is reflected in its moat. Beyond the upper bailey's postern gate is a dense forest of pine and spruce, as well as the steep, carved steps along the Giant's Lance.[2] Mules are kept at the Gates of the Moon to help transport travelers up the mountain to Stone, Snow, and Sky.[2]
92.name: Location: Gates of the Moon

93.content: White Harbor is a harbor city up north with the New Castle, the home of House Manderly. It's southeast of Winterfell and the biggest settlement in the north, though the smallest among the five major cities in Westeros. White Harbor is the main trading port in the north, thanks to its position at the mouth of the White Knife River, which allows for trade further north. Because of its location, White Harbor has more contact with the south of Westeros and has a diverse population. It's a clean and well-organized city, with wide straight streets made of cobblestone that are great for walking. The houses are made of whitewashed stone, and the roofs are steep and dark grey. The city is protected by city guards. White Harbor has access to a variety of seafood, and it's also known for its shipwrights and silversmiths. The city is famous for its beer. Ships often sail between White Harbor and the Three Sisters, trading wood, wool, and hides for crab, fish, and goat cheese. Fishfoot Yard is a square with a fountain in the middle, just outside the Seal Gate. There's an alley that leads to a brothel. The Lazy Eel is a tavern known for its old prostitutes, terrible wine, and inedible meat pies. The Sept of the Snows is a large sept with a domed roof and tall statues of the Seven. The New Castle is where House Manderly resides. It sits on a hill inside the city walls, and you can reach its gates from the Wolf's Den below by using the Castle Stair. There's a secret passage underneath the Castle Stair that connects the New Castle with the cellars of the Wolf's Den.
93.name: Location: White Harbor

94.content: Ser Addam Marbrand, a member of House Marbrand, is the son and heir of Lord Damon Marbrand of Ashemark. He is a trusted ally of House Lannister, acting as their bannerman. He has a lean and athletic build, with dark copper hair that falls to his shoulders. He is very brave, gallant and charming. He is highly skilled in horsemanship and swordfighting. Addam is a childhood friend of Jaime Lannister. He attends council meetings with Tywin, providing his insights.
94.name: Person: Addam Marbrand

95.content: House Blackmont of Blackmont is a major Dornish noble house. Their seat, Blackmont, is on the banks of the Torentine in the Red Mountains of Dorne. House Blackmont has very little Rhoynar ancestry compared to other Dornish houses, as they primarily descend from the First Men and Andals. This makes them light-haired and light-skinned. House Blackmont's sigil is a black vulture with a pink infant in its claws on a yellow field. Lady Larra Blackmont is the Lady of Blackmont and the head of the house. Jynessa Blackmont is her daughter and heir to Blackmont. Perros Blackmont is her son, a squire. Lady Larra has a few younger children who are among the favorite children hosted by Doran Martell, Prince of Dorne, at the Water Gardens.
95.name: House: Blackmont

96.content: House Gargalen of Salt Shore is a major Dornish noble house. Their seat, Salt Shore, is located along the Summer Sea on the southern coast of Dorne. Deceased Doran Martell, the former Prince of Dorne, squired for Lord Gargalen in his youth. The sigil of House Gargalen is a red cockatrice with a black snake in its beak on a golden field. Lord Tremond Gargalen, the Lord of Salt Shore, is the head of the house.
96.name: House: Gargalen

97.content: House Jordayne of the Tor is one of the principal noble houses of Dorne. The Tor is situated on the southern coast of the Sea of Dorne. Their sigil is a golden quill on checkered dark and light green. Their words are "Let it be Written". Lord Trebor Jordayne is the Lord of the Tor and the head of the house. Myria Jordayne is his daughter and heir to the Tor.
97.name: House: Jordayne

98.content: House Manwoody of Kingsgrave is an old Dornish noble house. Its seat, Kingsgrave, is placed amidst the Prince's Pass, guarding access to Dorne. The sigil of House Manwoody is a crowned skull on a black field. Their words are "No King Above Me". Lord Dagos Manwoody is the Lord of Kingsgrave and the head of the house. Mors Manwoody is his eldest son and heir. Dickon Manwoody is his second son. Ser Myles Manwoody is Dagos's brother.
98.name: House: Manwoody

99.content: House Qorgyle of Sandstone is a noble house from Sandstone, located in the dunes of western Dorne. They are among the principal bannermen sworn to House Martell of Sunspear. Members of House Qorgyle are known as Sandy Dornishmen, characterized by their dark olive skin and black hair. The sigil of House Qorgyle consists of three black scorpions on a crimson field. The words of House Qorgyle are "Fear Our Sting". Their home is an oasis amidst the sands. The house consists of Lord Quentyn Qorgyle, Lord of Sandstone; Ser Gulian Qorgyle, his eldest son and heir to Sandstone; Ser Arron Qorgyle, his second son.
99.name: House: Qorgyle

100.content: House Santagar of Spottswood is a house of landed knights from Spottswood in Dorne. They are sworn to House Martell. The Santagars are known for their martial prowess. The sigil of House Santagar is a spotted leopard with a golden axe on a blue and white field. The words of House Santagar are "Woe to Who Touches It". Ser Symon Santagar is the Knight of Spottswood and the current head of the house. Sylva Santagar, called "Spotted Sylva", is his daughter and heir to Spottswood. Sylva has many freckles. Sylva is married to Lord Eldon Estermont of Estermont.
100.name: House: Santagar

101.content: House Uller of Hellholt is one of the great noble houses in Dorne. Their keep, the Hellholt, is in the middle of the Dornish desert, and they are reputed to be impulsive and unpredictable. A Dornish saying is "Half of the Ullers are half-mad, and the other half are worse." Their arms are rayonne yellow over crimson. Lord Harmen Uller is Lord of Hellholt and the current head of the house. Ellaria Sand, his bastard daughter is a paramour to Prince Oberyn Martell and mother of four of his bastard daughters. Ser Ulwyck Uller is Harmen's brother.
101.name: House: Uller

102.content: Dragonstone is a castle on the island of the same name at the entrance to Blackwater Bay, below the Dragonmont. It was the original seat of House Targaryen in Westeros, and now Dragonstone is owned by Lord Stannis Baratheon, the younger brother of King Robert Baratheon. Shaped from stone to look like dragons, the castle has a dark reputation. The maesters at Dragonstone are Cressen and Pylos, and the castle's sept is maintained by Septon Barre. At least two members of House Blackberry serve at Dragonstone. Dragonstone was constructed by the Valyrians using mystical arts, fire, and sorcery. Throughout the castle, dragon motifs can be found, like small dragon sculptures adorning gates and dragon claws gripping torches. The armory and smithy are covered by a pair of grand wings, while dragon tails form archways and staircases. The citadel itself is crafted entirely from black stone. Dragonstone encompasses a castle yard and a library. Beneath the curtain walls lies a fishing village with a port. It has the Stone Drum, a colossal tower and central keep. To reach the Stone Drum from Sea Dragon Tower, one must cross the gallery and pass through the middle and inner walls. A high stone bridge, spanning emptiness, leads from the Stone Drum to the entrance of the dungeons. The top floor of the Stone Drum houses the Chamber of the Painted Table, where a large table intricately carved and painted as a map of Westeros can be found. The Great Hall, shaped like a massive dragon lying on its belly, features heavy red doors set within its mouth. The kitchens resemble a curled-up dragon, with smoke and heat venting through its nostrils. Sea Dragon Tower, resembling a dragon gazing calmly at the sea, contains the maester's chambers and the rookery. The Windwyrm is a tower shaped like a defiant screaming dragon. Aegon's Garden, accessed by descending past the arch of the Dragon's Tail, houses tall dark trees, wild roses, towering thorny hedges, and cranberries. The garden exudes a pleasant piney fragrance. The sept of Dragonstone, dedicated to the Faith of the Seven, houses statues carved from the masts of the ships that carried the first Targaryens from Valyria. Beneath Dragonstone, a turnpike stair and smooth stony passages lead to cells. The walls in the dark dungeon emit warmth when touched.
102.name: Location: Dragonstone

103.content: Jon Arryn is the Lord of the Eyrie, the Defender of the Vale, the Warden of the East and the head of House Arryn. Jon Arryn rebelled against the Mad King Aerys II Targaryen after he condoned the alleged kidnapping of Eddard Stark's sister, Lyanna, who was also betrothed to Robert Baratheon. After the rebel victory, Robert Baratheon became king and appointed Jon Arryn as his Hand. Jon Arryn married Lady Jeyne Royce as his first wife, but their daughter was stillborn. His second wife, Lady Rowena, died without issue. Jon Arryn's third and current wife was Lysa Tully is much younger than him. Their marriage was part of an alliance between House Arryn and House Tully. Jon and Lysa have a son, Robert. Jon acted as a second father to Lord Eddard Stark and King Robert when they were children. Jon has broad shoulders. Half of his teeth had fallen out by the time he married Lysa Tully. He has blue eyes, blond hair, and an aquiline nose. Lysa resents Jon's poor breath. Jon has a reputation for being prudent, calming and wise, and kindly and trusting. He is cordial but not friendly toward Lord Stannis Baratheon. Jon's blade has wings on its crossguard, a falcon-head pommel, and is engraved in silver to resemble mountain sky. Jon preferrs functional armor, rather than jeweled and silvered plate. Jon's favorite bird is a falcon gifted to him by Robert. Jon Arryn is around 60 years old.
103.name: Person: Jon Arryn

104.content: Robb Stark is the eldest son of Eddard Stark and Catelyn Tully and is the heir of House Stark to Winterfell and the north. He is called the Young Wolf by friend and foe alike. He is 14. Robb has a stocky build, blue eyes, and thick red-brown hair. He is strong and fast. He wields a longsword and an oak shield decorated with a direwolf's head. Robb is better with a lance than his half brother, Jon Snow, although Jon is more skilled with a sword. Robb is his father Eddard's son, with a keen sense of justice and courtesy. He shares his father's devotion to honor and is frequently accompanied by his direwolf, Grey Wind. He has a strong bond with his family, particularly with his father, whom he admires and looks up to. Robb shares a loving and caring relationship with his mother, Catelyn Stark. He respects her opinions and values her guidance. Robb's relationship with his sister Sansa is mostly positive. They have a typical sibling dynamic, with occasional disagreements and arguments. Robb is protective of Sansa and wants to ensure her well-being. Robb appreciates Arya's independent spirit and her determination to be her own person. Robb Stark and Jon Snow share a close and special bond. They spend a lot of time together, training in swordsmanship and learning the ways of the North. They share common interests and often confide in each other.
104.name: Person: Robb Stark

105.content: Catelyn Stark, also called Lady Stark, comes from House Tully, a notable family in Westeros. She was born and raised in Riverrun, the ancestral home of House Tully in the fertile Riverlands. Catelyn, the eldest daughter of Lord Hoster Tully, grew up with her younger siblings, Lysa and Edmure. At 16, Catelyn entered into an arranged marriage with Eddard Stark, the Lord of Winterfell and Warden of the North. Originally, Catelyn was supposed to marry Eddard's brother, Brandon Stark, but he died and she wed Ned instead. Together, Catelyn and Eddard have five children: Robb, Sansa, Arya, Bran, and Rickon. Catelyn deeply loves and cares for her children but dislikes Eddard's illegitimate son, Jon Snow, who lives with them in Winterfell. Catelyn Stark has a graceful and regal presence, with auburn hair and blue eyes, signature of the Tully family. She carries herself with poise, embodying authority and resilience. Known for her unwavering loyalty and strong sense of duty, Catelyn always puts her family's well-being first. She is a devoted wife and mother, prioritizing the needs of her loved ones over her own. Catelyn is intelligent and skilled in diplomacy, having a keen ability to judge character. She has some political influence through her childhood friend, Petyr Baelish, who is the king's master of coin and advisor in King's Landing. Catelyn shares a deep bond with her husband, Eddard Stark, based on trust, respect, and support. She is his closest confidante and advisor, offering counsel on political matters, although she still feels hurt by her husband's alleged infidelity, which the existence of a bastard son attests. Catelyn is cruel to Jon Snow because she reminds him of her husband's infidelity. Catelyn often thinks about getting revenge on Ned by letting others fuck her, the idea makes her horny, but her sense of duty prevents her from doing so. Catelyn actively participates in her children's education, teaching them the values of honor, loyalty, and duty. She also maintains strong relationships with her siblings, especially Lysa. Catelyn values her family connections and works to protect and strengthen them.
105.name: Person: Catelyn Stark

106.content: Eddard Stark, also known as "Ned," leads House Stark, rules Winterfell, and protects the North. He's a close friend of King Robert I Baratheon, they grew up together. Ned has a long face, dark grey eyes, brown hair, and a greying beard that makes him seem older than his thirty-five years. Eddard Stark is known for his strong sense of honor, duty, and loyalty. He is a man of integrity and principles, always striving to do what is right. Eddard is a devoted husband and father, and he values family above all else. He is respected by his bannermen and the people of the North for his fairness and just rule. Eddard is also known for his wisdom and ability to make sound judgments. He is a capable leader and administrator, effectively managing the affairs of House Stark and the North. He wields a sword and a dagger and has a Valyrian steel greatsword, Ice. Ned is proficient in combat. Ned was born at Winterfell as the second son of Lord Rickard Stark and Lady Lyarra Stark. He had an older brother named Brandon and two younger siblings, Lyanna and Benjen. From age eight, Ned lived with Lord Jon Arryn at the Eyrie and formed a strong bond with his ward, Robert Baratheon. Jon Arryn became a father figure to him. Lyanna Stark, Eddard's younger sister, was betrothed to Robert Baratheon but was allegedly kidnapped by Prince Rhaegar Targaryen, leading to Robert's Rebellion. Lyanna died during it and her death had a profound impact on Eddard. Eddard's father and brother were executed by King Aerys II Targaryen, the Mad King, which led to Eddard becoming the Lord of Winterfell and Warden of the North. Ned married Catelyn Tully and they have five children: Robb, Sansa, Arya, Bran, and Rickon. Ned also took Jon Snow to Winterfell and raised him as his own bastard son, despite the dishonor that came with it. Ned has never told anyone how Jon was conceived, leaving everyone to assume that he is his son. Catelyn and Eddard shares a strong bond, they have a loving and supportive marriage. Ned is cautious of Roose Bolton.
106.name: Person: Eddard Stark

107.content: Robert I Baratheon is the King and leader of House Baratheon in King's Landing. He is 35. He has two younger brothers, Stannis and Renly. He won the throne through conquest in the war known as Robert's Rebellion, which started when Rhaegar Targaryen, the Prince of Dragonstone, allegedly abducted Robert's betrothed, Lyanna Stark. Robert's victory at the Battle of the Trident, where he killed Rhaegar in a duel, turned the tide of the war in his favor. After the war, he married Cersei Lannister to solidify an alliance with House Lannister, but their marriage lacked love and respect. Robert and Cersei have three children: Joffrey, Myrcella, and Tommen. Robert has the typical Baratheon appearance, with black hair and bright blue eyes. He is a tall man, around six and a half feet tall. In his youth, Robert was handsome and clean-shaven, with rough hands. However, he gained a considerable amount of weight after Greyjoy's Rebellion due to excessive eating and drinking. His beard is thick and wild, hiding his double chin. Soldiers admire Robert for his bravery, but he can be headstrong, impulsive, and impatient. He is proud and stubborn, especially when under the influence of alcohol. As king, he is not accustomed to being challenged and can be easily manipulated by others. Tyrion Lannister sees him as a boastful fool, while Varys views him as a simple-minded individual. Cersei considers him ignorant, slow-witted, and lacking the ruthlessness she believes a king should possess. Petyr Baelish believes Robert deliberately turns a blind eye to unpleasant truths. In battle, Robert is as strong as a bull and fearless. He enjoys the clash of swords and despises poison as a cowardly weapon. He can show mercy to defeated enemies who display honesty and bravery, and he can inspire loyalty and friendship in those he spares. He holds a deep hatred for the Targaryens. Despite his physical decline, Robert remains a formidable man. Robert is notorious for his insatiable appetites and numerous affairs, resulting in many illegitimate children. However, he also possesses a reckless generosity. Robert's greatest strength lies in his ability to forge alliances and his charismatic leadership. Stannis recalls that men who fought against Robert during the day would often be drinking, feasting, and laughing with him in the evening. He has a good sense of humor and takes slights well openly on most occasions unless they are towards people he loves.
107.name: Person: Robert Baratheon

108.content: Kevan Lannister is a knight from House Lannister, the younger brother of Tywin Lannister, the older brother of Genna Lannister. He was born as the second son of Lord Tytos Lannister. Kevan is a big man with broad shoulders and a thick waist. His short blond hair is balding, and he has a close-cropped, yellow beard that follows the line of his massive jaw. Kevan has green eyes and fair skin. Kevan is devoted to his elder brother, Lord Tywin. He is tireless, prudent, and reliable, solid and steady. Despite being a household knight and not a lord, Kevan's strategic thinking, significant retinue, and personal wealth has made him a man of significant standing. Kevan was a confidant and companion for Tywin since childhood. Recognizing the competency of Tywin at an early age, Kevan did his best to realize his brother's wishes, though this meant perpetually living in his shadow. In contrast to Kevan, Tywin had stormy relations with his other brothers, Tygett and Gerion. At sixteen, Tywin had Kevan collect the outstanding debts owed to Casterly Rock, and those who could not pay immediately had to surrender a family member as a hostage till the debt was settled. As Ser Harys Swyft was not able to pay at the time, he handed his daughter Dorna into Kevan's custody. Kevan fell in love with Dorna and married her by 266 AC. Ser Kevan had four children with his wife: Lancel, twin boys Martyn and Willem, and a daughter, Janei. Kevan considers his wife a gentle soul, never comfortable except at home with friends and kin around her.
108.name: Person: Kevan Lannister

109.content: Storm's End is the stronghold of House Baratheon, the ruling family of the Stormlands. It sits on Durran's Point, along the northern coast of Shipbreaker Bay. The castle is south of Bronzegate and northeast of Griffin's Roost. The kingsroad runs north from Storm's End through the stormlands to King's Landing, the capital of the Seven Kingdoms. Renly Baratheon is the Lord of Storm's End, aided by Maester Jurne. The castle is surrounded by a massive outer curtain wall, reaching heights of one hundred feet and thicknesses of forty to eighty feet. The wall is made of pale grey stone with a sturdy core of sand and rubble. It has a smooth, curved design that prevents the wind from having any impact. On the seaward side, there's a sheer drop of one hundred fifty feet into the sea. Behind the curtain wall, you'll find the castle's kitchens, stables, and yard. Storm's End features a single tower, a colossal drum tower with imposing battlements. The main hall of the castle is called the Round Hall. At the top of the tower, one'll find the maester's cell and the rookery. In the godswood of Storm's End, there's a weirwood tree with a solemn face carved into its trunk.
109.name: Location: Storm's End

110.content: Theon Greyjoy, a member of House Greyjoy, is the only surviving son and future heir of Balon Greyjoy, the ruler of the Iron Islands. He has an older sister, Yara. Following the end of Greyjoy's Rebellion, Theon was taken as a hostage and placed under the care of Lord Eddard Stark in Winterfell. He is currently 14 years old. Theon is a slim and attractive young man with dark hair and a dark complexion. He finds amusement in almost everything and is known for his self-assured demeanor and smug smile. Despite his outward confidence, Theon hides insecurities relating to his uncertain familial and social identity. Theon seeks approval from the Starks, but usually feels unsatisfied. Skilled in hunting and horseback riding, Theon excels with the longbow and wields a dirk. He carries a longsword in a scabbard displaying the Greyjoy colors of black and gold. Theon considers himself a graceful dancer.
110.name: Person: Theon Greyjoy

111.content: House Baratheon of Storm's End is one of the Great Houses of Westeros, and is the principal house in the stormlands, which they rule as Lords Paramount of the Stormlands. Their seat, Storm's End, is an ancient castle raised by the Storm Kings from the now-extinct House Durrandon. The Baratheon sigil is a crowned black stag on a field of gold. Their words are "Ours is the Fury". After Robert's Rebellion, House Baratheon split into three branches: Lord Robert Baratheon was crowned king and took residence at King's Landing, thereby creating House Baratheon of King's Landing. Robert gave the seat of Dragonstone to his younger brother, Stannis, creating House Baratheon of Dragonstone. Robert's youngest brother, Renly, became the Lord of Storm's End, continuing House Baratheon of Storm's End. Members of the family tend to be tall and powerfully built, with black hair and blue eyes, as well as strong, square jawlines. They are known for their mercurial tempers. Vassals: House Caron, House Connington, House Dondarrion, House Errol, House Estermont, House Fell, House Grandison, House Lonmouth, House Morrigen, House Musgood, House Peasebury, House Penros, House Seaworth, House Selmy, House Swann, House Tarth, House Trant, House Wylde. Robert Baratheon: The head of House Baratheon, King of the Seven Kingdoms, married to Cersei Lannister. Queen Cersei Baratheon (formerly Lannister) - Robert's wife and queen consort. Prince Joffrey Baratheon - Robert and Cersei's eldest son and heir to the Iron Throne. Prince Tommen Baratheon - Robert and Cersei's younger son. Princess Myrcella Baratheon - Robert and Cersei's daughter.
111.name: House: Baratheon

112.content: Jaime is a member of House Lannister, the son of Tywin and Joanna Lannister. He is 34, exceptionally handsome, with golden hair and green eyes. He is known for his physical attractiveness and charm, which often captivates those around him. He has a twin sister, Cersei Lannister and a younger brother, Tyrion Lannister. Due to his position in the Kingsguard, Jaime cannot inherit his father's lands or titles. Jaime is arrogant and self-assured, often displaying a cocky and confident demeanor. He is known for his wit and sharp tongue, often engaging in clever banter and wordplay. Jaime doesn't mock others over minor insults the way Cersei does, and he can muster up polite behavior, but he is usually very blunt and straightforward. Jaime became extremely disillusioned with ideals of honor and loyalty when he saw firsthand the atrocities committed by the Mad King, how other "honorable" members of the Kingsguard stood by and did nothing while King Aerys had people burned alive for imagined insults. Jaime's reputation is tarnished by his infamous act of killing King Aerys II Targaryen, earning him the derogatory nickname "Kingslayer." Jaime was never politically ambitious, much to Cersei's annoyance, and often turns down her frequent urgings that he should try to become Hand of the King. Jaime is regarded as one of the best swordsmen in the Seven Kingdoms, known for his exceptional fighting skills and prowess with a sword. He is a skilled knight and a member of the Kingsguard, an elite group of knights sworn to protect the king. Jaime's combat abilities and martial skills are highly respected and feared by his adversaries. Jaime has a secret incestuous relationship with his twin sister, Cersei, which resulted in the birth of their three children: Joffrey, Myrcella, and Tommen. Jaime's relationship with his younger brother Tyrion is characterized by genuine affection and support. Jaime is the only member of Tyrion's immediate family who ever treated him with respect or kindness. In fact, he admires Tyrion's intellect and his ability to tell off those who insult him. Jaime never approved of Tywin and Cersei's long history of abuse towards Tyrion, and has always treated him like a brother. Jaime is the only member of the core Lannister family who has a reasonably good relationship with all of the others.
112.name: Person: Jaime Lannister

113.content: Cersei Lannister is the queen of the Seven Kingdoms, she's 34. She is the daughter of Lord Tywin Lannister and Joanna Lannister, and the older twin of Jaime Lannister, older sister to Tyrion Lannister. She grew up in Casterly Rock. From a young age, she was prepared for a life of power and influence. When Cersei was four, her mother died in childbirth, and she held a grudge against Tyrion, blaming him for her death. Cersei had hopes of marrying Rhaegar Targaryen, but that dream never came true. At 19, she wed King Robert Baratheon in a political alliance, becoming the Queen. Initially, Cersei was infatuated with Robert's handsome appearance. However, their love quickly faded as Robert continued to pine for his deceased love, Lyanna Stark, and even called Cersei by Lyanna's name on their wedding night. She bore a son with Robert, who tragically died shortly after birth. Cersei grew to resent Robert for his infidelity and his lack of affection towards her. She felt trapped in a loveless marriage and turned to Jaime for emotional and physical comfort, maintaining an incestuous relationship with him. Her three children, Joffrey, Myrcella, and Tommen, are officially recognized as Robert's heirs, but in reality, they are the offspring of Cersei and Jaime's secret relationship. Cersei Lannister is famous for her stunning appearance, with long, golden curls, a porcelain-like face, and green eyes. She exudes confidence and elegance, always adorned in lavish attire and jewelry. Ambitious, cunning, and merciless, Cersei will stop at nothing to protect and secure her family's power and position, often resorting to manipulation and betrayal. With a strong sense of entitlement, Cersei firmly believes in her destined greatness. Her love for her children knows no bounds, and she is willing to do whatever it takes to shield them from harm. Her talent for manipulation allows her to exploit others for her own gain. Cersei's relationship with her father Tywin Lannister is complex. She wants his approval and respect but often clashes with his expectations.
113.name: Person: Cersei Lannister

114.content:
Lys, known as Lys the Lovely, is one of the nine Free Cities of Essos. It is a small city clinging to rocks surrounded by stormy seas. The city lies off the coast of the Disputed Lands, to the southeast of Tyrosh and to the west of Volantis. It is usually used "Lyseni" as a noun, and "Lysene" as an adjective.

A mercantile city, Lys is built on a fertile island considered a paradise by Valyrian dragonlords. The sunny island is fertile with palm and fruit trees, and the surrounding blue-green waters are filled with fish.

Lys is protected by high walls and hired sellswords. A city dominated by wealth rather than by birth, Lys is where trade is considered a profession more honorable than arms. The city is known for its pillow houses and pleasure gardens.

Lys is deeply involved in the slave trade, with slaves outnumbering freeborn Lyseni three to one. Lys is most famous for their bed slaves, and Lyseni are known to be famously voracious in their search for comely young boys and fair maids for their pillow houses. Lys is also known for the breeding of slaves, mating beauty with beauty, hoping to produce the most lovely courtesans and bedslaves.

Lysene coins are oval in shape and have a naked woman stamped on them, the native love goddess of Lys.

Lys makes red and white wine, as well as fine tapestries. The alchemists of Lys are known to make poisons, including the strangler and the tears of Lys, and drugs like the powerfull lyseni juice. Heady sweet perfumes also come from the city. The Lyseni also make fine long dirks.
114.name: Location: Lys

115.content:
Pleasure houses, pleasure gardens or pillow houses are different terms used throughout the known world to refer to brothels that are typically of high quality.

Lys is full of pleasure houses catering to every taste, no matter how peculiar. One in particular is famed for its Naathi girls, who are clad in diaphanous silken gowns and adorned with gaily painted butterfly wings.

Summer Islanders held the belief that no shame can be found in pillow houses.

The most famous of these establishments is the Perfumed Garden.
115.name: Concept: Pleasure house

116.content:
The Perfumed Garden is a famous pillow house in Lys.

The Perfumed Garden was one of the many holdings owned by House Rogare under Lysandro "the Magnificent". In 135 AC, Lysandro drowned when his opulent barge sank whilst carrying him from the Perfumed Garden back to his palace.

A younger son of Lysandro, Fredo, inherited the Perfumed Garden. When the Rogare Bank ran dry, Fredo was put on trial, and the Rogare Bank was seized, along with the bed-slaves there. When the Rogare's assets proved insufficient to cover their debts, the Rogares were also sold into slavery, with the daughters of Lysaro and Fredo Rogare becoming bed-slaves in the Perfumed Garden.
116.name: Location: The Perfumed Garden

117.content: The Street of Silk is a street of King's Landing located on the Hill of Rhaenys leading up to the Dragonpit by the west. The street is known for its brothels of varying expense, including Chataya's brothel, the Blue Pearl, and Mother's
117.name: Location: Street of Silk

118.content:
Chataya's brothel, or Chataya's for short, is an upscale brothel on the Street of Silk in King's Landing. It is owned and run by Chataya. Her girls are costly and dress in flowing silks cinched at the waist with beaded belts.

The brothel is two stories tall with a stone ground floor and a timber upper floor. Many of its windows are leaded. Over the door swings an ornate lamp of gilded metal and scarlet glass.

Inside the entrance the air smells of exotic spice. Its floor displays a mosaic of two women entwined in love. The common room is behind an ornate Myrish screen that has been carved with flowers, fancies, and dreaming maidens. The common room has a cushioned alcove and a leaded colored glass window where sunlight pours through. An older man plays the pipes.

A round turret rises from one corner of the house. The turret room is located up two flights of stairs from the ground floor, then down a long hall and up another stair to a lone door which opens to the turret room. Within the room is a great canopied bed, a tall wardrobe decorated with erotic carvings, and a narrow window of leaded glass in a pattern of red and yellow diamonds.

Inside the turret room's empty wardrobe is a back panel concealing a secret passageway. When the back panel is pushed aside it reveals a metal ladder whose rungs go well below street level. The shaft then opens onto a dark, slanting earthen tunnel. Having come perhaps a distance of three blocks under the Hill of Rhaenys, a patron will then emerge through a trap door at the back of a nearby stable.

The secret tunnel from the brothel was dug for an unspecified Hand of the King.

The brothel is a favorite of King Robert I Baratheon. Lords Stannis Baratheon and Jon Arryn visited Chataya's brothel when trying to identify bastards fathered by Robert.

Chataya's girls: Alayaya, Dancy, Jayde, Marei and a dark-eyed dornish girl.

Known clients: Anguy, Bronn, Robert I Baratheon, Oberyn Martell and an unnamed Hand of the King (theorised to be Tywin Lannister)
118.name: Location: Chataya's brothel

119.content:
The Blue Pearl is a brothel in King's Landing on the Street of Silk.

According to Alys Turnberry, Ser Braxton Beesbury had fathered a bastard daughter on a whore at the Blue Pearl.

In 84 AC, two men of the City Watch of King's Landing found Tom Turnip, the fool of King Jaehaerys I Targaryen, surrounded by whores at the Blue Pearl, as well as Ser Braxton Beesbury, Lord Roy Connington, and Jonah Mooton, the male favorites of Princess Saera Targaryen. Lord Roy admitted they thought it would be funny to see the fool do the deed, and Jonah Mooton said the prank had been Saera's idea.
119.name: Location: Blue Pearl

120.content:
Mother's was a brothel on the lower end of the Street of Silk in King's Landing during the reign of King Aegon III Targaryen. The prostitutes employed there are referred to as "Mother's daughters".

Former Grand Maester Orwyle, who had escaped his imprisonment, hid and worked in the brothel during the Regency of Aegon III under the alias of "Old Wyl"
120.name: Location: Mother's

121.content: Dorne is the southernmost part of the continent of Westeros. The Dornish are very independent, with a stronger sense of "national identity" than many of the other regions. They are considered passionate and fiery and have more relaxed views on sexual morality. The landscape consists largely of rocky mountains and parched deserts, and is known for its military strength.
121.name: Location: Dorne

122.content:
Lyseni juice is a highly addictive sexual drug little known in Westeros but widely used in the region of Essos, especially in the city of Lys.

A simple drop of this purple substance can unleash sexual frenzy in those unaccustomed to its consumption. Its powerful effects appear within minutes and can take days to dissipate. There is nothing that can stop the effects of the drug. Those who consume it experience sexual arousal close to madness and will feel stimulated by any contact, being able to reach powerful orgasms with the simple touch of their clothing. Those who are under its effects can reach overwelming orgasms which often end up corrupting the minds of those who abuse the substance.

It has some side effects such as the withdrawal syndrome, insomnia and the development of long-term perversions. The withdrawal syndrome consists of a state of constant sexual arousal, the appearance of twisted sexual fantasies and the impossibility of reaching orgasm if not through the substance.

The drug is commonly used to train slaves and prostitutes in the pleasure houses of Lys, many of them become addicted to the substance. It can also be found in the underworld of Kings Landing and in some brothels throughout Westeros. It is usually stored in vials that contain multiple doses that are usually consumed sip by sip. A whole vial is considered a large amount for a single person if taken at one time.
122.name: Concept: Lyseni Juice

123.content:
Maesters are an order of intellectuals (scholars, healers, and other learned men).
They also serve as the resident medical expert at a castle, responsible for everything from setting broken bones, assisting childbirth, and knowledge of medicinal herbs and potions to aid fevers and internal illnesses.
123.name: Concept: Maesters

124.content:
House Clegane is a house of landed knights in the westerlands. They hold fealty to House Lannister of Casterly Rock, and are among their primary bannermen. Their lands are southeast of the Rock and include a towerhouse, which, according to a semi-canon source, is named Clegane's Keep. Their sigil depicts three dogs on a yellow field.

The first Clegane of House Clegane was kennelmaster at Casterly Rock. During one autumn year he saved Lord Tytos Lannister from a lioness, although he lost a leg and three dogs while doing so. Lord Tytos rewarded him with lands and a towerhouse. Ser Clegane's son was placed in Tytos's service as his squire. For his sigil Ser Clegane used the three dogs he lost saving Tytos, on the yellow of autumn grass.

The kennelmaster's son, the father of Gregor and Sandor, died in a hunting accident. Their sister died young under queer circumstances. Gregor is known for his unspeakable cruelty; this is mirrored in the Mountain's men, who casually commit atrocities during their campaigns. Sandor was driven away by this behavior, taking service with House Lannister and refusing to take a knight's vows to avoid association with his elder.

Gregor was knighted by Prince Rhaegar Targaryen, the heir of King Aerys II Targaryen. During the Sack of King's Landing, Gregor murdered Rhaegar's son, the infant Prince Aegon Targaryen, before raping and murdering his mother and Rhaegar's bride, Princess Elia Martell.
124.name: House: Clegane

125.content:
Sandor Clegane is a member of House Clegane and is the younger brother of Ser Gregor Clegane. Sandor is nicknamed the Hound for his fierce nature and unquestioning obedience to House Lannister and for the three dogs featured in his family's arms.

As a child, Sandor received gruesome facial burns when Gregor shoved his face into a brazier. He has come to loathe fire, his brother, and the hypocrisy of knighthood in general. The sworn shield of Prince Joffrey Baratheon, Sandor is considered one of the most dangerous fighters in Westeros

Sandor is a huge and heavily-muscled man. He has grey eyes, his nose is large and hooked, and his long hair is dark and thin. One side of Sandor's face is gaunt, with sharp cheekbones and a heavy brow, while the other side is a burned ruin of scars. Slick black flesh is pocked with craters and deep cracks that ooze red and wet, his ear is only a hole with a stump, and a hint of bone shows on his jaw. The scars extend down to his throat. There is a twisted mass of scars around his eye, which is still good, not harmed by the fire, but he has no lips on that side. Sandor brushes his hair so that it covers his burned side, since no hair grows there. Sandor speaks in a rough, rasping voice, and has a laugh "like the snarling of dogs in a pit." The burnt corner of his mouth twitches when he speaks.

Sandor is taller than King Robert I Baratheon, Brienne of Tarth, Lord Renly Baratheon, and Ser Jaime Lannister, but shorter than Hodor and Lord Jon Umber. Jaime regards Sandor as one of the strongest living men in Westeros, but the Kingslayer thinks he could defeat the Hound's strength with his own speed and skill.

The cynical Sandor dislikes knighthood and has a temper, but he is dutiful and likes dogs. He often makes fun of Tyrion Lannister because of the dwarf's height, which amuses Prince Joffrey Baratheon. According to Lord Varys, Sandor gambles and patronizes whores and winesinks, having a preference for young innocent-looking teenage girls whom he calls little birds. Sandor hates and fears fire, but will carry a torch or light a campfire when needed.

The Hound regularly wears an olive-green cloak over plain, soot-dark armor, and a distinctive helm sculpted into the shape of a snarling dog's head. He also sometimes wears a brown roughspun tunic and studded leather jerkin. He also has worn a red woolen tunic with a leather dog's head sewn on the front. When wearing the white woolen cloak of the Kingsguard, he fastens it with a jeweled brooch. Sandor wields a longsword, a warhammer, and a dagger, and can wield an axe. His stallion is a heavy courser named Stranger. He has had at least one unnamed squire.
125.name: Person: Sandor Clegane

126.content:
Gregor Clegane is the Knight of Clegane's Keep and the head of House Clegane, a landed knight and bannerman to House Lannister of Casterly Rock. Gregor is a freakishly large man and for this he is often called the Mountain That Rides or simply the Mountain. His soldiers are known as the Mountain's men.

Gregor is well known for his size, cruelty, and prowess in battle. He is extremely tall, being well over seven feet tall, closer to eight. (somewhere in between 2,31 m and 2,43 m) He has "massive shoulders and arms thick as the trunk of small trees", and a voice like stone breaking. Gregor weighs over thirty stone (420 lbs, or 190 kgs), nearly all of it muscle, making him near inhumanly strong. Ser Jaime Lannister when pondering who is physically stronger than him, thinks that both the Clegane brothers are for a certainty, but that of the two, the Mountains strength is like nothing human.

As a young boy, eleven or twelve years old, Gregor caused his brother Sandor's facial scars by holding the younger boy's face to a hot brazier as punishment for playing with a toy he had discarded. Their father spread the story that the injuries were caused by bedding that had caught fire.

At the age of seventeen, Gregor participated in the Sack of King's Landing during Robert's Rebellion. He and Ser Amory Lorch scaled Maegor's Holdfast when the Lannister troops reached the Red Keep. Gregor entered the nursery of the infant Prince Aegon, son of Prince Rhaegar, and killed the baby present by dashing the boy's head against a wall. Then he raped and murdered Aegon's mother, Princess Elia, supposedly with the boy's blood and brains still on his hands. The identities of the two murderers have not been publicly confirmed in the recorded history, although Gregor's involvement is common knowledge at Casterly Rock.

Gregor wears the heaviest, thickest steel plate armor in the Seven Kingdoms. Dull grey in color and battle-scarred, his armor is so heavy that no ordinary man would be able to move, let alone fight effectively while wearing it. Below the plate he wears chainmail and boiled leather. He also wears a plate helm with only a narrow slit for vision, atop of which is a stone fist punching up towards the sky. The Mountain's strength allows him to wield a six-foot, two-handed greatsword with just one hand, giving him enormous reach while still wielding a shield. Such is the power of Gregor's strength that he has been known to hack men in half with just a single blow. Gregor's massive oaken shield is rimmed in black iron, and it bears the three black dogs of House Clegane on a yellow field. He rides huge stallions, one of which is as ill-tempered as its rider.

The violent Gregor is a sadistic murderer and rapist. Lady Catelyn Stark thinks he has an evil reputation, and Ser Brynden Tully compares him to a "frothing dog". Despite being a dim and brutal man, he has excellent warrior instincts. The Mountain is solitary, never leaving his own lands except for wars or tourneys.
126.name: Person: Gregor Clegane

127.content:
Milk of the poppy is used as a pain killer or anesthetic in the Known World. It is normally given to those mortally wounded or in great pain. It has a quick effect of causing sleep, even for people in great pain. During this sleep, people often have strange "poppy dreams". Milk of the poppy also has an incapacitating effect, "filling your head with clouds", even after the user has woken from sleep. Because of this, and possibly because it is also addictive or because overuse causes tolerance, some prefer to go through strong pain instead of consuming it. Overuse of milk of the poppy may make the user's face become puffy.

In Meereen, some pit fighters dull their nerves with milk of the poppy before going out to die in the fighting pits. Victors will drink milk of the poppy afterwards for the pain of their wounds.

Dothraki herbwomen make a derivative of milk of the poppy called "poppy wine". Wine mixed with poppy juice can also be made by a maester, to ease pain.
Poppy fields grow in Essos, near Volon Therys.
127.name: Concept: Milk of the poppy

128.content:
Alayaya, sometimes called Yaya, is a prostitute working at the whorehouse owned by her mother, Chataya, in King's Landing. She is a Summer Islander, but was born in King's Landing.

Alayaya is a beautiful young Summer Islander, with skin as smooth and black as polished jet, and wide dark eyes. She is taller than Shae, but not as tall as her own mother. She dresses in flowing silks, cinched at the waist with a beaded belt.

Alayaya speaks the Common Tongue with only a light accent. She is learning to read. Of her, Tyrion feels that "a sweeter, braver, more innocent girl he had seldom met"
128.name: Person: Alayaya

129.content: Dancy has a pug-nose, freckles and long, thick red hair.
129.name: Person: Dancy

130.content: Jayde is a whore at Chataya's brothel in King's Landing. She is addicted to lyseni juice.
130.name: Person: Jayde

131.content:
Marei is a whore at Chataya's brothel in King's Landing. Marei has green eyes and porcelain skin. Marei has green eyes and white-gold hair, which matches the common physical traits of members of House Lannister. Tyrion Lannister describes her long straight hair as being silvery on one occasion and pale white-gold on another. Marei is older than Shae. 

Tyrion Lannister notices Marei once or twice during his visits to Chataya's brothel. Marei bets that Dancy, a fellow whore at Chataya's, can not convince Tyrion to come upstairs with her. If she had won, she would have received Dancy's black pearls. Marei teaches some of the other prostitutes how to read.

The solemn Marei is literate, Marei is said to have a solemn demeanor, matching Tywin's personality. Marei is theorized to be a bastard daughter of Tywin Lannister, fathered during his tenure as Hand of the King. A secret passageway leads from the brothel where Marei is employed to a stable three blocks underneath Rhaenys's Hill. According to Varys, the secret passageway was built on the orders of a Hand of the King "whose honor would not allow him to enter such a house openly". The name of the Hand is not specified by Varys, but several readers have suggested that this description could fit Tywin.
131.name: Person: Marei

132.content: Dunsen is one of the Mountain's men, the men-at-arms in service to Ser Gregor Clegane.
132.name: Person: Dunsen

133.content: Polliver is a man-at-arms among the Mountain's men in service to Ser Gregor Clegane. Polliver is near as tall as Sandor Clegane, but not as heavily muscled.[3] He has a thick, black, spade-shaped beard that is neatly trimmed, covering his jaws and jowls. His head is more bald than not.
133.name: Person: Polliver

134.content: The Mountain's men are men-at-arms of the westerlands in service to Ser Gregor Clegane, the Mountain That Rides. The Mountain's men are a dangerous, unsavory bunch, grim and foul mouthed. The best that can be said for Gregor's men is that they are not quite as vile a bunch as the Brave Companions. Sandor Clegane refers to his brother's soldiers as Gregor's "pet rats". According to Sandor, Gregor once killed one of his men for snoring. Gregor never brings his men-at-arms to court in King's Landing, the only exception is Joss Stilwood who serves as his squire. They often refer to Gregor simply as "Ser".
134.name: Concept: Mountain's men

135.content:
The Brave Companions are a sellsword company of considerably ill repute from Essos. The company comprises criminals and outcasts from many nations.

Led by Vargo Hoat of Qohor, the band is often called the Bloody Mummers for their brutality and outlandish appearance, though they find this name insulting. They are also called the Footmen for Vargo's practice of cutting off the hands and feet of prisoners and the Toes of the Goat for their standard, which depicts a black goat with bloody horns, symbolizing the Black Goat of Qohor.

Unlike most soldiers, the vile and violent Brave Companions are considered to be malignantly cruel; their reputation is even worse than that of the Second Sons under Mero.

According to semi-canon sources, the Brave Companions are not as old as other mercenary companies and were established before Vargo Hoat became their leader. Their numbers consist of the scum of the west, and a few from the east and the south. Their previous leader was likely not a Qohorik, and their next might possibly be a Lyseni, a Dornishman or even an Ibbenese.

Their diverse ranks are said to include copper men with bells in their braids;[4] lancers astride black-and-white horses; bowmen with powdered cheeks; squat hairy men with shaggy shields;[4] brown-skinned men in feathered cloaks; swordsmen with fantastic forked beards dyed green and purple and silver; spearmen with colored scars that cover their cheeks; Myrish crossbowmen, pale Lyseni; and dark Dornishmen
135.name: Concept: Brave Companions

136.content:
Vargo Hoat, sometimes called the Goat, is a sellsword from Qohor who leads the Brave Companions mercenary company.

Although Vargo Hoat does not appear in the television adaptation Game of Thrones, the character Locke, played by Noah Taylor, is based on him.

Vargo is a tall and gaunt man. He has a two-feet-long ropey black goatee dangling from a pointed chin. A large tongue causes Vargo to lisp and slobber when he speaks.

Vargo is more cunning than he seems. He is a sadist who frequently tortures his prisoners by chopping off their hands and feet, earning him an additional nickname, "the Crippler".

Vargo wears a chain of linked coins from all the places where he has fought. The coins are of every shape and size, cast and hammered, bearing the likenesses of kings, wizards, gods, demons, and all manner of fanciful beasts. Vargo rides a zorse. His coat of arms feature the Black Goat of Qohor and he wears a helm shaped as a goat's head.

Vargo and the Brave Companions were brought across the narrow sea by Lord Tywin Lannister.

After having caught a venereal disease, Vargo began sending women to be examined by Qyburn as a precautionary measure, before raping them.
136.name: Person: Vargo Hoat

137.content:
Roose Bolton is the Lord of the Dreadfort and the head of House Bolton. He is convinced that regular leechings improve a person's health, and as such frequently has himself leeched, which has led to some calling him the Leech Lord.

Roose has an unremarkable body, neither plump, thin, nor muscular. He has pasty skin and a pallid chest, which is soft and hairless. Roose has short, strong fingers. He has a plain face, beardless and ordinary, with his only noticeable feature being his strange eyes, paler than stone and darker than milk, like two white moons. The color is sometimes called "ghost grey". His eyes are paler than those of his son, Ramsay.

Though mild-mannered, Roose is remorseless and implacable. He is considered to be cold and cunning. Roose's voice is small and soft; he rarely raises his voice, forcing those who listen to do so intently, falling silent. Roose sips his alcohol, preferring hippocras, or hot spiced wine, although he is also willing to drink ale and regular wine. Roose's personal motto is "A peaceful land, a quiet people".

Roose often wears black ringmail and a red-spotted pale pink cloak, trimmed with white fur. He also owns a suit of dark grey plate armor over a quilted tunic of blood-red leather. Its rondels are shaped like human heads whose mouths are open in agony. Its helmet has streamers of red silk which flutter in the wind. Usually worn with it is a pink woolen cloak embroidered with droplets of blood. Roose wields sword and dagger.

Roose practices the abolished tradition of the first night, but he is discreet with his activities and amusements in order to avoid the attention and possible ire of the Wardens of the North, House Stark. While hunting along the Weeping Water, Roose once raped a young miller's wife and hanged the miller for not gaining his approval for their marriage. When the woman later presented a baby to Roose, he spared the bastard boy Ramsay because he had the same pale eyes as Roose. Lord Bolton granted the mill to the woman, sent her annual supplies and funds, and had the tongue of the miller's brother cut out to prevent Lord Rickard Stark from learning what had happened.

Roose fought at the Battle of the Trident during Robert's Rebellion. When Ser Barristan Selmy, seriously wounded, was brought before Lord Robert Baratheon, Roose counselled that they should kill him. Robert ignored Roose and spared Barristan's life, sending his own maester to tend to the Kingsguard's wounds.
137.name: Person: Roose Bolton

138.content:
Ramsay Snow is the bastard son of Roose Bolton, Lord of the Dreadfort and head of House Bolton, and is known as the Bastard of Bolton and the Bastard of the Dreadfort.

Ramsay has a group of men-at-arms who stand high in his favor and follow him loyally, although their true allegiance lies with Lord Roose. They are called the Bastard's Boys, though never within their or Ramsay's hearing, and are just as depraved as Ramsay. Ramsay's personal steed is named Blood, and he keeps a pack of female hunting hounds.

Ramsay is an ugly young man, even when dressed finely. He is big boned and slope shouldered, with a fleshiness indicating he will be fat later in life. Ramsay's skin is pink and blotchy, his nose broad, his hair long and dark and dry. Although his mouth is small, Ramsay's lips are wide and meaty, wormy looking, and he smiles a wet-lipped smile. His distinctive eyes resemble Roose's - small, close-set, and oddly pale, like two chips of dirty ice. Ramsay sometimes wears a garnet cut in the shape of a drop of blood in his right ear.

Ramsay's attire includes calfskin boots, velvet doublet, silver-chased swordbelt, and a sable cloak. He also sometimes wears a black leather jerkin over a pink velvet doublet slashed with dark red satin, along with black boots, belt, and scabbard.[8] For battle Ramsay wears dark armor with a red helm and a pale pink cloak. His rounded helm and gorget resemble the face and shoulders of a skinless and bloody man whose mouth is open in a silent scream.

Ramsay's weapons include a falchion, a dagger, and a flaying knife, all with hilts of yellow bone.

Ramsay considers himself a true Bolton despite his birth and is highly resentful of his baseborn status, referring to himself proudly as the trueborn scion of the Dreadfort and violently correcting those who refer to him otherwise.

Ramsay is a sadist; he is cruel, savage and wild, taking delight in torturing others. He is quite fond of the old House Bolton custom of flaying their enemies alive.

Ramsay is a cunning and capable manipulator. He is particularly good at thinking on his feet, though less savvy when it comes to long-term consequences and intricate politics. He openly enjoys abusive practices such as having young women stripped naked and released into the Bolton forests, before hunting them with a pack of feral dogs. He gives a quick death to women who give him good sport (after raping them first), then flays their corpses. He likes to name his dogs after the women he enjoys most to "honor" them. The women who do not give him good sport are raped and then flayed alive. The skins of his kills are brought back with him to the Dreadfort as gruesome trophies. The bodies of the woman are fed to his dogs.

Ramsay's father, Lord Roose Bolton, chides him for his "amusements", and encourages Ramsay to incorporate his creed of "a peaceful land, a quiet people" into his own, if Ramsay ever hopes to rule. Roose states that Ramsay is fearless, which is a bad thing, as fear keeps a man alive in a treacherous world.

Ramsay, though savage in battle, was never officially taught at arms. His tutor in martial prowess is Reek, his serving man, who has never received any sword training himself. Ramsay's swordsmanship style is vicious and highly aggressive, wielding his sword as if it were a butcher's cleaver.
138.name: Person: Ramsay Snow

139.content:
The Free Cities, also called the Nine Free Cities, are a group of nine independent city-states in western Essos, located west of the Dothraki sea and the Painted Mountains and northwest of the Valyrian peninsula.

The Free Cities trade and interact frequently with the Seven Kingdoms of Westeros. Many in the Free Cities consider themselves more sophisticated than Westerosi, with some considering the people of the Seven Kingdoms to be savages.
139.name: Location: Free Cities

140.content:
Lorath is one of the Nine Free Cities. It is in a group of islands in the Shivering Sea, near the northern coast of Essos. 

Lorath is on the west side of the largest of three islands surrounded by stormy seas. It is at the mouth of Lorath Bay and, except Braavos, is the northernmost of the Free Cities. The second-largest island is Lorassyon, but there are a score of smaller isles. To the south of the isles is a thickly forested peninsula. The Lorathi also claim dominion over the waters of Lorath Bay, but fishing fleets from Braavos and whalers and sealers out of Ib often venture into the bay, for Lorath does not have sufficient strength to make good its claim. To the east is the Axe and the west Braavos. Morosh at the Sarne delta is a Lorathi colony. The Lorathi isles are bleak and stony, but in their waters plenty of cod, whales, and grey leviathans can be found, and colonies of walrus and seal.

The followers of Boash did not eat flesh, nor drink wine. They went about barefoot, dressing in hair shirts and hides, and their priests were eunuchs who wore eyeless hoods. The cult of Boash believed in extreme self-abnegation, and because all humans were equal before their god, they considered women to be equal to men in all matters, nor did they practice slavery. This denial of the self extended to the point that adherents came to refer to themselves and others using indefinite pronouns; they did not use names, and referred to themselves as "a man" and "a woman", instead of saying "I", "me", or "mine". While the cult of Boash has long gone extinct, certain of these speaking habits are still used in Lorath today. Nobles regard it as vulgar to speak of one's self directly. When one of the Faceless Men of Braavos uses the identity of "Jaqen H'ghar" of Lorath, he uses this speech pattern.

Lorath used to be ruled by three princes: the Harvest Prince, the Fisher Prince, and the Prince of the Streets. These princes, once chosen, served for life. All are chosen by vote: the Harvest Prince by those who own land upon the islands, the Fisher Prince by all who own ships, and the Prince of the Streets by the acclamation of the free men of the city. While the council of princes still exists today, their titles have become ceremonial. The actual rule of Lorath now resides with a council of magisters made up of nobles, priests, and merchants.
140.name: Location: Lorath

141.content:
Boash, also called the Blind God, is a deity that was once worshiped in the Valyrian Freehold. His followers settled on the main isle of Lorath. His worshippers are referred to as Boash'i.
